<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
December&nbsp;9, 2003, the last reported sale price of our common stock as reported on the Nasdaq National Market was $2.31 per share. As of December&nbsp;9, 2003, there were
24,917,671 shares of our common stock outstanding held by approximately 291 holders of record. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Dividend Policy  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have never paid cash dividends on our common stock. We currently intend to retain earnings, if any, to fund the development and growth of our business and do
not anticipate paying cash dividends for the foreseeable future. Payment of future cash dividends, if any, will be at the discretion of our board of directors after taking into account various
factors, including our financial condition, operating results, current and anticipated cash needs and plans for expansion. In addition, our Amended and Restated Accounts Receivable Financing Agreement
with Silicon Valley Bank, dated as of April&nbsp;4, 2003, as amended, provides for certain limitations on the payment of dividends by us on our common stock. Furthermore, under the terms of our
Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock, we may not pay dividends on our </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>16</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=17,EFW="2125104",CP="SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=332998,FOLIO='16',FILE='DISK012:[03BOS8.03BOS2708]DG2708A.;11',USER='TMCKINN',CD='23-DEC-2003;11:22' -->
<A NAME="page_dg2708_1_17"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>common
stock without the consent of the holders of at least 75% of the outstanding shares of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Recent Sales of Unregistered Securities  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;22, 2003, we issued to FuelCell Energy&nbsp;Inc., in connection with a materials financing arrangement, a warrant exercisable for 250,000 shares
of our common stock, at an exercise price of $0.72 per share. This warrant expires on July&nbsp;21, 2006. This warrant was issued in reliance upon the exemptions from registration under
Section&nbsp;4(2) of the Securities Act or Regulation&nbsp;D promulgated thereunder, relative to sales by an issuer not involving any public offering. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
December&nbsp;12, 2003, we issued to Silicon Valley Bank, in connection with the sixth amendment to the Amended and Restated Accounts Receivable Financing Agreement, dated
December&nbsp;12, 2003, a warrant exercisable for 16,164 shares of our common stock, at an exercise price of $2.32 per share. This warrant expires on December&nbsp;11, 2010. This warrant was
issued in reliance upon the exemptions from registration under Section&nbsp;4(2) of the Securities Act or Regulation&nbsp;D promulgated thereunder, relative to sales by an issuer not involving any
public offering. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dg2708_item_6._selected_consolidated_financial_data"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dg2708_6"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 6. SELECTED CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL DATA    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;You should read the data set forth below in conjunction with "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations" and our
consolidated financial statements and related notes appearing elsewhere in this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K. The selected consolidated financial data set forth below for our fiscal
years ended September&nbsp;30, 2003, 2002 and 2001 and the consolidated balance sheet data as of September&nbsp;30, 2003 and 2002 are derived from our audited consolidated financial statements
appearing elsewhere in this Annual Report on
Form&nbsp;10-K. The selected consolidated statement of operations data for our fiscal years ended September&nbsp;30, 2000 and 1999 and the consolidated balance sheet data as of
September&nbsp;30, 2001, 2000 and 1999 are derived from our audited consolidated financial statements that are not included in this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dk2708_item_7._management_s_discussio__ite03668"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dk2708_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Special Note Regarding Forward-Looking Information  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K contains or incorporates forward-looking statements within the meaning of section&nbsp;27A of the Securities
Act of 1933 and section&nbsp;21E of the Securities Act of 1934. You can identify these forward-looking statements by our use of the words "believes," "anticipates," "plans," "expects," "may,"
"will," "intends," "estimates," and similar expressions, whether in the negative or in the affirmative. Although we believe that these forward-looking statements reasonably reflect our plans,
intentions and expectations, our actual results could differ materially from the plans, intentions and expectations disclosed in the forward-looking statements we make. We have included important
factors in the cautionary statements below under the heading "Factors Affecting Future Results" that we believe could cause our actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements
that we make. We do not intend to update information contained in any forward-looking statements we make. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Recent Developments  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On October&nbsp;31, 2003, we completed a $7.7&nbsp;million financing transaction involving the issuance of 1,535 shares of our Series&nbsp;B Convertible
Preferred Stock, and warrants to purchase up to 1,228,000 shares of our common stock, from 25 accredited investors. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
connection with the financing, we issued shares of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock for $5,000 per share. The Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock is convertible into a number of shares of
common stock equal to $5,000 divided by the conversion price of the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock, which is $2.50. The total number of shares of common stock issuable upon conversion of the shares
of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock issued and sold is 3,070,000. The Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock accrues dividends of 6% per annum, increasing to 8% per annum on October&nbsp;1, 2005. The
dividend for the first six months was paid at closing by issuing 76,054 shares of common stock, valued based on the average of the closing bid and ask price of the common stock on the Nasdaq National
Market for the five trading days preceding October&nbsp;31, 2003. All
further dividends will be paid on a semi-annual basis. Except in certain limited circumstances, we may opt to pay these dividends in cash or in shares of common stock. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
part of the financing, we also issued warrants to purchase up to 1,228,000 shares of common stock. These warrants have an initial exercise price of $3.32 per share, which represents
110% of the average closing price of our common stock for the five trading days prior to October&nbsp;31, 2003. These warrants are immediately exercisable and expire on October&nbsp;31, 2008. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
November&nbsp;2003, with the proceeds from this financing transaction, we paid off the outstanding balance under our line of credit with Silicon Valley Bank (the "Bank") of
$1.8&nbsp;million and the Bank released $0.4&nbsp;million of the $0.5&nbsp;million of cash previously restricted. In addition, on December&nbsp;12, 2003, we amended our agreement with the
Bank. Under the amended agreement, the Bank will provide us with a line of credit of up to approximately $6.3 million (the "Amended Loan"). The Amended Loan is secured by most of the assets of the
Company and advances under the Amended Loan are limited to 80% of eligible accounts receivables, which will permit borrowings up to $5.0 million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Overview  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SatCon designs, develops and manufactures high-efficiency high power electronics and a variety of standard and custom high-performance
machines for specific applications. SatCon's power control products convert, store and manage electricity for businesses and consumers, the U.S Government and military that require
high-quality, uninterruptible power. SatCon is utilizing its engineering and manufacturing expertise to develop products that it believes will be integral components of distributed </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>20</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=21,EFW="2125104",CP="SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=732167,FOLIO='20',FILE='DISK012:[03BOS8.03BOS2708]DK2708A.;16',USER='TMCKINN',CD='23-DEC-2003;11:30' -->
<A NAME="page_dk2708_1_21"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>power
generation and power quality systems. SatCon's specialty motors are typically designed and manufactured for unique customer requirements such as high power-to-size
requirements or high efficiency. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SatCon
has expanded its business and capabilities through the following acquisitions: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>K&amp;D
MagMotor Corp.&#151;a manufacturer of custom electric motors, acquired in January&nbsp;1997.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Film
Microelectronics,&nbsp;Inc.&#151;a manufacturer of hybrid microelectronics, acquired in April&nbsp;1997.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Inductive
Components,&nbsp;Inc.&#151;a value-added supplier of customized electric motors, acquired in January&nbsp;1999.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Lighthouse
Software,&nbsp;Inc.&#151;a supplier of control software for machine tools, acquired in January&nbsp;1999.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>HyComp,&nbsp;Inc.&#151;a
manufacturer of electronic multi-chip modules, acquired in April&nbsp;1999.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Ling
Electronics,&nbsp;Inc.&#151;a manufacturer of test equipment, power converters, amplifiers and converters, acquired in October&nbsp;1999.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Inverpower
Controls&nbsp;Ltd.&#151;a manufacturer of power electronics modules and advanced high-speed digital controls, acquired in July&nbsp;2001. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, in November&nbsp;1999, the Company acquired intellectual property, tooling and other assets from Northrop Grumman Corporation enabling the Company to manufacture and sell
electric drivetrains and in September&nbsp;2002, we acquired certain intellectual property, equipment and other assets from Sipex Corporation to expand our high-reliability data
conversion product line. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Critical Accounting Policies and Significant Judgments and Estimates  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of our operations are based on our consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared
in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America. The preparation of these consolidated financial statements requires management to make estimates and
assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported revenue and
expenses during the reporting periods. On an ongoing basis, management evaluates its estimates and judgments, including those related to revenue recognition,
receivable reserves, inventory reserves, investment in Beacon Power Corporation, goodwill and intangible assets and income taxes. Management bases its estimates on historical experience and on various
other factors that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying value of assets and liabilities that are not
readily apparent from other sources. Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
significant accounting policies that management believes are most critical to aid in fully understanding and evaluating our reported financial results include the following: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Revenue Recognition  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We recognize revenue from product sales in accordance with SEC Staff Accounting Bulletin No.&nbsp;101, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revenue
Recognition</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. Product revenue is recognized when there is persuasive evidence of an arrangement, the fee is fixed or determinable, delivery of the product to the customer has
occurred and we have determined that collection of the fee is probable. Title to the product passes upon shipment of the product, as the products are typically shipped FOB shipping point, except for
certain foreign shipments. If the product requires installation to be performed by us, all revenue related to the product is deferred and recognized upon the completion of the installation. If the
product requires specific </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>21</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=22,EFW="2125104",CP="SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=624006,FOLIO='21',FILE='DISK012:[03BOS8.03BOS2708]DK2708A.;16',USER='TMCKINN',CD='23-DEC-2003;11:30' -->
<A NAME="page_dk2708_1_22"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>customer
acceptance, revenue is deferred until customer acceptance occurs or the acceptance provisions lapse, unless we can objectively and reliably demonstrate that the criteria specified in the
acceptance provisions are satisfied. We provide for a warranty reserve at the time the product revenue is recognized. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
perform funded research and development and product development for commercial companies and government agencies under both cost reimbursement and fixed-price contracts. Cost
reimbursement contracts provide for the reimbursement of allowable costs and, in some situations, the payment of a fee. These contracts may contain incentive clauses providing for increases or
decreases in the fee depending on how costs compare with a budget. On fixed-price contracts, revenue is generally recognized on the percentage of completion method based upon the proportion of costs
incurred to the total estimated costs for the contract. Revenue from reimbursement contracts is recognized as services are performed. In each type of contract, we receive periodic progress payments or
payment upon reaching interim milestones and retain the rights to the intellectual property developed in government contracts. All payments to us for work performed on contracts with agencies of the
U.S. government are subject to audit and adjustment by the Defense Contract Audit Agency. Adjustments are recognized in the period made. The Defense Contract Audit Agency has agreed-upon
the final indirect cost rates for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2000. When the current estimates of total contract revenue and contract costs for product development contracts indicate a
loss, a provision for the entire loss on the contract is recorded. Any losses incurred in performing funded research and development projects are recognized as funded research and development expenses
as incurred. As of September&nbsp;30, 2003 and 2002, we have accrued approximately $0.4&nbsp;million and $0.2&nbsp;million, respectively, for anticipated contract losses. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cost
of product revenue includes material, labor and overhead. Costs incurred in connection with funded research and development and other revenue arrangements are included in funded
research and development and other revenue expenses. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Deferred
revenue consists of payments received from customers in advance of services performed, product shipped or installation completed. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unbilled
contract costs and fees represent revenue recognized in excess of amounts billed due to contractual provisions or deferred costs that have not yet been recognized as revenue or
billed to the customer. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Accounts Receivable  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Accounts receivable are reduced by an allowance for amounts that may become uncollectible in the future. The estimated allowance for uncollectible amounts is
based primarily on a specific analysis of accounts in the receivable portfolio and historical write-off experience. While management believes the allowance to be adequate, if the financial
condition of our customers were to deteriorate, resulting in impairment of their ability to make payments, additional allowances may be required. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Inventory  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We value our inventory at the lower of actual cost to purchase and/or manufacture the inventory or the current estimated market value of the inventory. We
periodically review inventory quantities on hand and record a provision for excess and/or obsolete inventory based primarily on our estimated forecast of product demand, as well as based on historical
usage. Due to the custom and specific nature of certain of our products, demand and usage for products and materials can fluctuate significantly. A significant decrease in demand for our products
could result in a short-term increase in the cost of inventory purchases and an increase of excess inventory quantities on hand. In addition, our industry is characterized by rapid
technological change, frequent new product development, and rapid product obsolescence that could result in an increase in the amount of obsolete inventory quantities on hand. Therefore, although we
make every effort to ensure the accuracy of our forecasts of future product </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>22</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=23,EFW="2125104",CP="SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=15589,FOLIO='22',FILE='DISK012:[03BOS8.03BOS2708]DK2708A.;16',USER='TMCKINN',CD='23-DEC-2003;11:30' -->
<A NAME="page_dk2708_1_23"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>demand,
any significant unanticipated changes in demand or technological developments could have a significant impact on the value of our inventory and our reported operating results. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
the end of June&nbsp;2003, we were actively engaged in selling our Shaker product line, and we were pursuing a strategy which we hoped would lead to a strategic alliance with a
larger company for the development and exploitation of the advantages embodied in our Uninterruptible Power Supply ("UPS") system. During the process of considering various options, we concluded that
both our Shaker and UPS system inventories were overvalued based upon the June&nbsp;2003 plans. We analyzed the situation and recorded in increase to our valuation reserve. This reserve was based on
our assessment of the situation as of that time. Events in the future could be materially different than expected. Late in calendar year 2003, we decided to retain our Shaker product line, due in part
to a significant improvement in our liquidity situation. In light of the plan to retain the Shaker product line, we have not reversed the valuation reserves we established in June&nbsp;2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Investment in Beacon Power Corporation  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On September&nbsp;28, 2001, we distributed 5,000,000 shares of Beacon Power common stock to our stockholders. Upon the distribution of the 5,000,000 shares, we
recorded the distribution of the 5,000,000 shares as a reduction of additional paid-in capital based on the book value per share prior to the distribution, or $0.59 per share. After the
distribution, we owned 4,705,910 shares, or approximately 11.0%, of Beacon Power's outstanding voting stock. Additionally, we had determined that we did not have the ability to exercise significant
influence over the operating and financial policies of Beacon Power and, therefore, accounted for our investment in Beacon Power using the fair value method as set forth in Statement of Financial
Accounting Standards ("SFAS") No.&nbsp;115, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for Certain Debt and Equity Securities.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> The investment was carried at fair value and designated
as available for sale and any unrealized holding gains or losses were to be included in stockholders' equity as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) so long as any unrealized
losses were deemed temporary in nature. If the decline in fair value was judged to be other than temporary, the cost basis was written down to the fair value as a new cost basis and the amount of the
write-down was included in the statement of operations. The new cost basis would not be changed for subsequent recoveries in fair value. Subsequent increases in the fair value were to be
included in stockholders' equity as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income (loss). Subsequent decreases in fair value, if not an other-than-temporary impairment,
also were to be included in stockholders' equity as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income (loss). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of September&nbsp;30, 2002, the quoted fair market value of Beacon Power's common stock held by us was $0.17 per share, or $0.8&nbsp;million. Our historical cost basis in our
investment in Beacon Power's common stock was approximately $0.59 per share, or $2.8&nbsp;million, resulting in an unrealized loss of $2.0&nbsp;million as of September&nbsp;30, 2002. We
determined that of this $2.0&nbsp;million, $1.4&nbsp;million represented an other than temporary decline based on the extent and length of the time the stock price has been below its cost as well
as its assessment of the financial condition and near term prospects of Beacon Power. We recorded a charge of $1.4&nbsp;million in the statement of operations to realize this portion of the loss.
This charge was measured based on the trading value of Beacon Power's common stock during the month of November and early December and was less than the gross unrealized loss due to subsequent
recovery of Beacon Power's stock price, as well as our ability and intent to hold the stock for a long enough period of time for it to recover to the new cost basis. After this write-down,
the new cost basis of the Beacon Power common stock held by us was approximately $0.30 per share and the unrealized loss of the Beacon Power common stock held by us was $0.6&nbsp;million as of
September&nbsp;30, 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of March&nbsp;29, 2003, the quoted fair market value of Beacon Power's common stock held by us was $0.18 per share, or $0.8&nbsp;million. Our cost basis in our investment in
Beacon Power's common stock was approximately $0.30 per share, or $1.4&nbsp;million, resulting in an unrealized loss of $0.5&nbsp;million as of March&nbsp;29, 2003. As of March&nbsp;29, 2003,
we believed the difference in the current fair market value and </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>23</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=24,EFW="2125104",CP="SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=791898,FOLIO='23',FILE='DISK012:[03BOS8.03BOS2708]DK2708A.;16',USER='TMCKINN',CD='23-DEC-2003;11:30' -->
<A NAME="page_dk2708_1_24"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>the
cost basis of our investment represented an other than temporary decline based upon our ability and intent to hold the stock for a long enough period of time for it to recover. We recorded a
charge of $0.5&nbsp;million in our statement of operations to realize this loss. After the write-down, the new cost basis of the Beacon Power stock held by us was $0.18 per share. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
June and July&nbsp;2003, we sold all of our 4,705,910 shares of our Beacon Power Corporation common stock for proceeds of $1.7&nbsp;million, net of fees and commissions. As a
consequence of the sale of these shares, we realized a gain of $0.9&nbsp;million, which is included in our results for the fiscal year ending September&nbsp;30, 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following summarizes our investment in Beacon Power Corporation: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, we have a warrant to purchase 173,704 shares of Beacon Power's common stock that has an exercise price of $1.25 per share and expires in 2005. We account for this warrant in
accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;133</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>, Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, and, therefore, record the warrant at its fair value.
As of September&nbsp;30, 2003 and 2002, the warrant to purchase Beacon Power common stock had a fair value of $0.1&nbsp;million and $0.0&nbsp;million, respectively. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Goodwill and Intangible Assets  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Purchase accounting requires extensive use of accounting estimates and judgments to allocate the purchase price to the fair market value of the assets purchased
and liabilities assumed. We have accounted for our acquisitions using the purchase method of accounting. Values were assigned to goodwill and intangible assets based on third-party independent
valuations, as well as management's forecasts and projections that include assumptions related to future revenue and cash flows generated from the acquired assets. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective
October&nbsp;1, 2001, we adopted the provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;142, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. This statement
affects our treatment of goodwill and other intangible assets. The statement requires impairment tests be periodically repeated and on an interim basis, if certain conditions exist, with impaired
assets written down to fair value. Additionally, existing goodwill and intangible assets must be assessed and classified within the statement's criteria. Intangible assets with finite useful lives
will continue to be amortized over those periods. Amortization of goodwill and intangible assets with indeterminable lives ceased. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
determine the fair value of each of the reporting units based on a discounted cash flow income approach. The income approach indicates the fair value of a business enterprise based on
the discounted value of the cash flows that the business can be expected to generate in the future. This analysis is largely based upon projections prepared by us and data from sources of publicly
available information available at the time of preparation. These projections are based on management's best estimate of future results. In making these projections, we consider the markets we are
addressing, the competitive environment and our advantages. There will usually be differences between estimated and actual results as events and circumstances frequently do not occur as expected, and
those differences may be material. In addition, we perform a macro assessment of the overall likelihood that we would </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>24</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=25,EFW="2125104",CP="SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=1043279,FOLIO='24',FILE='DISK012:[03BOS8.03BOS2708]DK2708A.;16',USER='TMCKINN',CD='23-DEC-2003;11:30' -->
<A NAME="page_dk2708_1_25"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>achieve
the projected cash flows and performed sensitivity analysis using historical data as the basis for projected cash flows. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Long-Lived Assets  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of October&nbsp;1, 2002, we adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;144, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived
Assets</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, which supercedes SFAS No.&nbsp;121, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for the Impairment of Long-Lived Assets and for Long-Lived Assets to be
Disposed Of</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, and the accounting and reporting provisions of APB Opinion No.&nbsp;30. SFAS No.&nbsp;144 addresses financial accounting and reporting for the impairment or
disposal of long-lived assets. The statement requires that long-lived assets be reviewed for possible impairment, if certain conditions exist, with impaired assets written down
to fair value. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
determine the fair value of certain of the long-lived assets based on a discounted cash flow income approach. The income approach indicates the fair value of a
long-lived assets based on the discounted value of the cash flows that the long-lived asset can be expected to generate in the future over the life of the
long-lived asset. This analysis is based upon projections prepared by us. These projections represent management's best estimate of future results. In making these projections, we consider
the markets we are addressing, the competitive environment and our advantages. There will usually be differences between estimated and actual results as events and circumstances frequently do not
occur as expected, and those differences may be material. In addition, we perform a macro assessment of the overall likelihood that we would achieve the projected cash flows and performed sensitivity
analysis using historical data as the basis for projected cash flows. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Income Taxes  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The preparation of our consolidated financial statements requires us to estimate our income taxes in each of the jurisdictions in which we operate, including
those outside the United States, which may be
subject to certain risks that ordinarily would not be expected in the United States. The income tax accounting process involves estimating our actual current exposure together with assessing temporary
differences resulting from differing treatment of items, such as deferred revenue, for tax and accounting purposes. These differences result in the recognition of deferred tax assets and liabilities.
We must then record a valuation allowance to reduce our deferred tax assets to the amount that is more likely than not to be realized. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant
management judgment is required in determining our provision for income taxes, our deferred tax assets and liabilities and any valuation allowance recorded against deferred
tax assets. We have recorded a full valuation allowance against our deferred tax assets of $41.1&nbsp;million as of September&nbsp;30, 2003, due to uncertainties related to our ability to utilize
these assets. The valuation allowance is based on our estimates of taxable income by jurisdiction in which we operate and the period over which our deferred tax assets will be recoverable. In the
event that actual results differ from these estimates or we adjust these estimates in future periods we may need to adjust our valuation allowance which could materially impact our financial position
and results of operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Results of Operations  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Fiscal Year Ended September&nbsp;30, 2003 Compared to Fiscal Year Ended September&nbsp;30, 2002  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Product Revenue.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Product revenue decreased by $9.2&nbsp;million, or 30%, from $30.8&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2002 to
$21.6&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2003. The decrease in revenue was comprised of $7.5&nbsp;million in our Power Systems Division and $1.7&nbsp;million in our Electronics Division. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
decline of $7.5&nbsp;million in Power Systems was due to significantly lower sales in all product lines. Approximately two-thirds of this variance was in our Power
Conversion and Test&nbsp;&amp; Measurement product lines; we also experienced reductions in our Magnetics and Motors and Service and Parts </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>25</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=26,EFW="2125104",CP="SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=899920,FOLIO='25',FILE='DISK012:[03BOS8.03BOS2708]DK2708A.;16',USER='TMCKINN',CD='23-DEC-2003;11:30' -->
<A NAME="page_dk2708_1_26"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>product
lines. These lower sales reflect an overall general weakness in our business. During the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2003, we shipped two UPS systems to third
parties&#151;one a 250 kilowatt unit and one a 2.2 megawatt unit. Both transactions had conditions which were not fulfilled as of September&nbsp;30, 2003; therefore we continued to defer this
revenue. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
decrease of $1.7&nbsp;million in Electronics revenue reflected the continued weakness in the telecommunication and semiconductor industries. In part because of general economic
weakness, we experienced lower sales in both our commercial and military sectors. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Funded research and development and other revenue.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Funded research and development and other revenue decreased by
$5.5&nbsp;million, or 51%, from $10.8&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2002 to $5.3&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2003. This decrease was attributable to the reduction in revenue of $2.5&nbsp;million
from a program with the Department of Energy to develop low-cost power conversion modules for electric and hybrid-electric vehicles ("AIPM"), and $0.5&nbsp;million from a program with
General Atomics for the U.S. Navy's electric missile air launch system ("EMALS"). These reductions were the results of these programs being completed. In addition, the decrease was attributable to a
reduction in revenue of $1.9&nbsp;million from programs with General Atomics to develop integrated power systems for future U.S. Navy's "all-electric" ship platforms ("IPS") and to
deliver modular, electric power converter and control assemblies to be installed on the RV Triton, a British research vessel ("TRITON)". During fiscal year 2003, we began work on a $1.1&nbsp;million
program with EDO Corporation ("EDO") for the design and development of a power converter for a new mine sweeping system for the U.S. Navy's Organic Airborne and Surface Influence Sweep system
("OASIS"). We have deferred recognizing revenue on this program until the contract is complete. As of September&nbsp;30, 2003, we have deferred $0.7&nbsp;million of costs associated with this
program. We expect this program to be completed in the third fiscal quarter of 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cost of product revenue.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cost of product revenue decreased by $3.6&nbsp;million, or
12</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>%,</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> from $29.6&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2002 to $26.0&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2003. This was primarily due to lower material costs of
$2.2&nbsp;million directly related to our decline in revenue. We also experienced a reduction of $2.7&nbsp;million in manufacturing and overhead costs reflecting a reduction in the cost structure
of the business. These reductions were offset in part by a higher provision for excess and obsolete inventory and purchase commitments of $1.3&nbsp;million primarily related to inventory for our
Shaker and UPS system products. In general, our businesses operate on negative margins at the current revenue levels due to excess manufacturing capacity, which is expensed as incurred. Since our cost
structure, except for materials, is relatively fixed, our revenue levels significantly affect our gross margin. The large drop in revenue for the year coupled with the valuation adjustment, were the
major reasons why our product gross margin declined from 4% in fiscal year 2002 to -20% in fiscal year 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Funded research and development and other revenue expenses.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Funded research and development and other revenue expenses
decreased by $2.1&nbsp;million, or 30%, from $7.2&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2002 to $5.0&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2003. The decrease was directly attributable to the reduction in funded
research and development revenue. The gross margin on funded research and other revenue declined from 34% in fiscal year 2002 to 5% in fiscal year 2003. In large part, this decline is reflective of
the fact that there is a significant fixed overhead component in our funded research and development and other revenue expenses. During fiscal year 2003, we entered into a fixed-price contract with
EDO for OASIS. We expect to incur costs in excess of the contract value and accordingly have accrued for this loss of $0.6&nbsp;million in the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2003. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unfunded research and development expenses.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unfunded research and development expenses decreased by $4.4&nbsp;million, or
75%, from $5.9&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2002 to $1.5&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2003. During fiscal year 2002, we were involved in developing the UPS product line in Power Systems which is
largely completed. This is the major reason for the reduction in unfunded research and </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>26</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=27,EFW="2125104",CP="SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=470002,FOLIO='26',FILE='DISK012:[03BOS8.03BOS2708]DK2708A.;16',USER='TMCKINN',CD='23-DEC-2003;11:30' -->
<A NAME="page_dk2708_1_27"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>development.
In addition, we have greatly reduced our development of radio frequency activity in our Electronics Division and terminated the biosensor activity in our Applied Technology Division. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Selling, general and administrative expenses.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Selling, general and administrative expenses decreased by $2.3&nbsp;million,
or 14%, from $15.9&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2002 to $13.6&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2003. This decrease was the direct result of cost savings including the restructuring activities completed
during the last half of fiscal year 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Amortization of intangibles.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Amortization of intangibles decreased by $0.1&nbsp;million, or 14%, from $0.6&nbsp;million
in fiscal year 2002 to $0.5&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2003. This was the result of the write-off of intangible assets as described below. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Restructuring costs.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During April&nbsp;2002, we commenced a restructuring plan designed to streamline our production base,
improve efficiency and enhance our competitiveness and recorded a restructuring charge of $1.5&nbsp;million. The restructuring charge included approximately $0.6&nbsp;million for severance costs
associated with the reduction of approximately 60 employees, or 17% of the work force. The reductions occurred in the following business segments: Applied Technology&#151;9:
Corporate&#151;2; Electronics&#151;16; and Power Systems&#151;33. On a functional basis, the reductions were: manufacturing&#151;45; research and development&#151;4;
and selling, general and administrative&#151;11. The balance of the restructuring charge relates to the closing of the Anaheim, CA facility. These costs include approximately
$0.3&nbsp;million of cash charges primarily related to rent, real estate taxes and operating costs to be paid through the remainder of the lease and an estimated $0.3&nbsp;million of other cash
charges for restoration and clean-up. In addition, approximately $0.2&nbsp;million of the restructuring charge relates to non-cash charges on assets disposed of. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Write-off of long-lived assets.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We recorded a $0.7&nbsp;million charge representing an impairment
in the carrying value of the long-lived assets in our Worcester, Massachusetts manufacturing facility. This was required as a result of our decision to streamline our operations. We have
decided to reduce our UPS sales, marketing and development effort and plan to form&nbsp;a strategic alliance with a major company. In this scenario, our Worcester facility will have the Magnetics
(Servo Motors and its Maglev products), EPT and StarSine as its remaining product lines. Based in large part on our recent history, we prepared a cash flow forecast of these products over the
7&nbsp;years&#151;representing the current lease and our 5-year option to extend&#151;we do not expect to recoup the value of our long-lived assets. These
assets, before write-down, approximate $3.2&nbsp;million and are comprised primarily of leasehold improvements made within the last few years.
Given this situation, we performed a fair market analysis of this asset and determined that a $0.7&nbsp;million charge was required in our fiscal third quarter representing an impairment of this
long-lived asset. Late in calendar 2003, we decided to retain our Shaker product line due in part to a significant improvement in our liquidity situation. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Write-off of impaired goodwill and intangible assets.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the three months ended March&nbsp;29, 2003, we
experienced a significant adverse change in the business climate, in particular, significant reductions in revenue and cash flows. This coupled with our current liquidity issues at that time, required
us to consider selling assets unrelated to our engineering and manufacturing expertise in electromechanical systems. The assets and product lines we considered selling included our Ling Shaker product
line, our patented smart predictive line control technology utilized by the electric arc steel manufacturing industry and patents acquired from Northrop Grumman related to the hybrid electric
vehicles. Based on these conditions, we performed an impairment test on an interim basis. We determined the fair value of each of the reporting units based on a discounted cash flow income approach.
This analysis was largely based upon historical data. Based on the results of the first step of the goodwill impairment test, we determined that the fair value of the Applied Technology and
Electronics reporting units exceeded their carrying amounts and, therefore, no goodwill impairment existed as of March&nbsp;29, 2003. As a result, the second step of the goodwill impairment test was
not required to be completed. We will continue to perform a goodwill impairment test for these reporting units on an annual basis and on an interim basis, if certain </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>27</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=28,EFW="2125104",CP="SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=727911,FOLIO='27',FILE='DISK012:[03BOS8.03BOS2708]DK2708A.;16',USER='TMCKINN',CD='23-DEC-2003;11:30' -->
<A NAME="page_dk2708_1_28"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>conditions
exist. Based on the results of the first step of the goodwill impairment test, we determined that the fair value of the Power Systems reporting unit does not exceed its carrying amount. The
fair value was determined to approximate the fair value of the net tangible assets. The second step of the impairment test required us to write off the unamortized balance of the goodwill and
intangible assets of the Power Systems reporting unit as of March&nbsp;29, 2003 of $5.8&nbsp;million. Late in calendar 2003, we decided to retain our Shaker product line due in part to a
significant improvement in our liquidity situation. However, we continue to consider selling our patented smart predictive line control technology utilized by the electric arc steel manufacturing
industry and patents acquired from Northrop Grumman related to hybrid electric vehicles. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net unrealized gain (loss) on warrants to purchase common stock.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net unrealized gain on warrants to purchase common stock in
fiscal year 2003 was $0.1&nbsp;million as compared with a net unrealized loss of $0.5&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2002. We account for our warrants to purchase Mechanical Technology Incorporated's
common stock and to purchase Beacon Power Corporation's common stock in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;133 and, therefore, we have recorded these warrants at their fair value at September&nbsp;30,
2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unrealized loss on Series&nbsp;B warrants.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unrealized loss on Series&nbsp;B warrants in fiscal year 2003 was
$1.9&nbsp;million. We account for our Series&nbsp;B warrants issued in connection with the February&nbsp;2003 financing transaction in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;133 and, therefore, we have
recorded these warrants at their fair value at September&nbsp;30, 2003. Because we did not achieve certain financial conditions for our fourth quarter of fiscal year 2003, the exercise price of
these warrants was to be reduced from $1.50 per share
down to $1.00 per share commencing on the date we file this Form&nbsp;10-K. Accordingly, we considered this fact in determining the fair value at September&nbsp;30, 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Write-down of investment in Beacon Power Corporation common stock/ Realized gain from sale of Beacon Power Corporation common stock.
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> We account for our investment in Beacon Power using the fair value method as set forth in SFAS No.&nbsp;115. As of March&nbsp;29, 2003, the quoted fair
market value of Beacon Power's common stock held by the Company was $0.18 per share, or $0.8&nbsp;million. Our cost basis in our investment in Beacon Power's common stock was approximately $0.30 per
share, or $1.4&nbsp;million, resulting in an unrealized loss of $0.5&nbsp;million as of March&nbsp;29, 2003. As of March&nbsp;29, 2003, we believed the difference in the current fair market
value and the cost basis of our investment represents an other than temporary decline based upon our ability and intent to hold the stock for a long enough period of time for it to recover. We
recorded a charge of $0.5&nbsp;million in the statement of operations to realize this loss. After the write-down, the new cost basis of the Beacon Power stock held by us was $0.18 per
share. During June&nbsp;2003, we commenced the sale of the 4,705,910 shares of our Beacon Power Corporation common stock. As of September&nbsp;30, 2003, we had sold all of those shares for
proceeds of $1.7&nbsp;million, net of fees and commissions. As a consequence of the sale of these shares, we realized a gain of $0.9&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest income (expense), net.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest expense, net was $4.0&nbsp;million for fiscal year 2003 compared with interest
income, net of $0.1&nbsp;million for fiscal year 2002, an increase in interest expense of $4.1&nbsp;million. Interest expense for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2003 includes the
following: $0.1&nbsp;million fees associated with the line of credit; $0.2&nbsp;million of interest expense associated with outstanding amounts under the line of credit; $0.3&nbsp;million of
expense associated with the issuance of warrants in connection with the line of credit; $0.1&nbsp;million of fess associated with forbearances of loan covenant violations; $0.1&nbsp;million on
capital lease obligations; $2.5&nbsp;million amortization of discount on the convertible redeemable Series&nbsp;A preferred stock; $0.2&nbsp;million dividends on convertible redeemable
Series&nbsp;A preferred stock; and $0.4&nbsp;million of amortization of discount on the convertible subordinated debentures. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>28</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=29,EFW="2125104",CP="SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=330603,FOLIO='28',FILE='DISK012:[03BOS8.03BOS2708]DK2708A.;16',USER='TMCKINN',CD='23-DEC-2003;11:30' -->
<A NAME="page_dk2708_1_29"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Fiscal Year Ended September&nbsp;30, 2002 Compared to Fiscal Year Ended September&nbsp;30, 2001  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Product Revenue.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Product revenue remained flat at $30.8&nbsp;million. Power Systems was down 1% from $20.2&nbsp;million
in 2001 to $19.9&nbsp;million in 2002. This was offset by an increase in the Electronics Division from $10.6&nbsp;million in 2001 to $10.9&nbsp;million in 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Within
Power Systems, revenue from magnetic levitation and high performance motor products declined 35% from $7.2&nbsp;million in 2001 to $4.7&nbsp;million in 2002. This decrease was
due in large part to
the decline in revenue from magnetic levitation products due to the weak semiconductor industry. In addition, revenue from vibration test equipment ("Shaker") was down 39% from $12.2&nbsp;million in
2001 to $7.5&nbsp;million in 2002. This reduction in Shaker revenue was due in part to the disruption caused by the relocation of the business from Anaheim, CA to Worcester, MA during the last half
of 2002. These decreases were more than offset by an increase in revenue from power conversion products from $0.8&nbsp;million in 2001 to $7.7&nbsp;million in 2002. This increase was due largely
to the fact that Inverpower was acquired in July&nbsp;2001 and, as a result, represented less than three months of business in 2001. Revenue from power conversion products in 2002 included
$2.4&nbsp;million from our StarSine Power Conditioning System ("PCS") to FuelCell Energy, $1.8&nbsp;million from our Inverpower Brand Smart Predictive Line Controllers ("SPLC") to Hatch
Steltech,&nbsp;Ltd. and $0.3&nbsp;million from a 250-kilowatt power conversion system to Siemens Westinghouse. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Despite
the weak telecom and semiconductor industries, the Electronics Division was able to increase revenue by 3% from $10.6&nbsp;million in 2001 to $10.9&nbsp;million in 2002. The
increase was due to an increase in revenue from the defense sector, which during 2002 represented approximately 69% of the total Electronics Division revenue. This compared with approximately 63% in
2001. In addition, on September&nbsp;27, 2002, we acquired the hybrid product line from Sipex Corp. and were able to ship $0.2&nbsp;million of product during 2002. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Funded research and development and other revenue.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Funded research and development and other revenue decreased by
$0.1&nbsp;million, or 1% from $10.9&nbsp;million to $10.8&nbsp;million. The largest change was the increase of $1.7&nbsp;million from $2.7&nbsp;million to $4.4&nbsp;million in funded
research and development revenue from a program with General Atomics to develop high power converter assemblies for the U.S. Navy's next generation of modern "all-electric" ships offset by
decreases of $0.6&nbsp;million from $3.1&nbsp;million to $2.5&nbsp;million from a Department of Energy program to develop low-cost power conversion modules for electric and
hybrid-electric vehicles and $0.6&nbsp;million from $1.1&nbsp;million to $0.5&nbsp;million with General Atomics from the U.S. Navy's electric missile air launch system program. During 2002, we
received all of the funding under the Department of Energy contract of $10.0&nbsp;million and completed final hardware deliveries in the first half of fiscal year 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Cost of product revenue.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> Cost of product revenue increased by $1.8&nbsp;million, or 7%, from $27.8&nbsp;million to
$29.6&nbsp;million. The increase was attributable to $3.8&nbsp;million of increased cost of product revenue from Power Systems from $17.6&nbsp;million to $21.4&nbsp;million. This increase was
offset in part by a decrease in the Electronics Division of $2.0&nbsp;million from $10.1&nbsp;million in 2001 to $8.1&nbsp;million in 2002. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Within
Power Systems, power products accounted for $6.1&nbsp;million of the increase due primarily to the full year effect of the Inverpower acquisition. This increase was offset by a
decrease of $2.3&nbsp;million in the Shaker, magnetic levitation and high performance motors cost of product revenue, which all experienced volume reductions in 2002. Inventory obsolescence charges
for Power Systems products totaled $1.9&nbsp;million in 2002 compared with $0.2&nbsp;million in 2001. These charges in 2002 represented $1.0&nbsp;million in power conversion products,
$0.6&nbsp;million in Shakers and $0.3&nbsp;million in other products. We purchased significant quantities of inventory related to our power conversion products during 2001 and 2002. When the
primary customer for these products became insolvent in 2002, we determined not to continue in this line of business and as a consequence the inventory that we maintained was no longer salable in the
ordinary course of business and had to be substantially reserved. As a consequence, our reserves against inventory as a percentage of gross inventory rose from 15.2% at the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>29</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=10,SEQ=30,EFW="2125104",CP="SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=349850,FOLIO='29',FILE='DISK012:[03BOS8.03BOS2708]DK2708A.;16',USER='TMCKINN',CD='23-DEC-2003;11:30' -->
<A NAME="page_dk2708_1_30"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>end
of fiscal year 2001 to 23.6% at the end of fiscal year 2002. With the exception of certain materials that were scrapped, we have not disposed of the inventory that was the subject of the
obsolescence charge. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Electronics Division was able to realize a decrease in its cost of product revenue despite a 3% increase in revenue. This decrease was primarily due to lower spending resulting from
its restructuring program, and, to a lesser extent, lower material costs as a percentage of revenue. Charges for inventory obsolescence were $0.4&nbsp;million in each year. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
general, our businesses operate on thin margins at the current revenue levels. Our cost structure, except for materials, is relatively fixed and includes such costs as manufacturing
labor, facilities and equipment. Gross margin from product revenue as a percentage of product revenue decreased from 10% in 2001 to 4% in 2002. During 2002, we increased our fixed costs significantly
as a result of relocating our Power Systems main facility from a 17,000 square foot facility to a 65,000 square foot facility. In addition, we began depreciating significant capital improvements we
made to this facility. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Funded research and development and other revenue expenses.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Funded research and development and other revenue expenses
decreased by $0.3&nbsp;million, or 4%, from $7.4&nbsp;million in 2001 to $7.2&nbsp;million in 2002. The largest change was the increase of $1.2&nbsp;million from $1.9&nbsp;million to
$3.1&nbsp;million in funded research and development revenue expenses from a program with General Atomics to develop high power converter assemblies for the U.S. Navy's next generation of modern
"all-electric" ships offset by a decrease of $0.4&nbsp;million from $0.8&nbsp;million to $0.4&nbsp;million from a program with General Atomics for the U.S. Navy's electric missile
air launch system program. In addition, we provided an additional provision of $0.1&nbsp;million for contract losses during 2002. Although revenue from the Department of Energy program to develop
low-cost power conversion modules for electric and hybrid-electric vehicles decreased by $0.6&nbsp;million, the costs remained flat at $1.9&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unfunded research and development expenses.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unfunded research and development expenses decreased by $0.4&nbsp;million, or
6%, from $6.2&nbsp;million in 2001 to $5.9&nbsp;million in 2002. The decrease is due to the near completion of the internally funded research and development projects including the power inverter
for
an on-site power generation system and our 250 kilowatt and 2.2 megawatt rotary UPS and power quality systems. The Company has not yet derived any revenue from this investment. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Selling, general and administrative expenses.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Selling, general and administrative expenses increased by $2.3&nbsp;million,
or 17%, from $13.6&nbsp;million in 2001 to $15.9&nbsp;million in 2002. The increase was primarily due to the full-year inclusion of Inverpower for 2002 and to a lesser extent the
increase in business development costs, primarily in the Applied Technology Division. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Write-off of public offering costs.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;25, 2001, we converted our registration statement initially
filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on October&nbsp;30, 2000 to a shelf registration statement. We expensed during 2001 $1.4&nbsp;million of equity financing costs incurred in
connection with this initial registration statement. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Amortization of goodwill and intangibles.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> Amortization of goodwill and intangibles decreased by $0.8&nbsp;million, or 57%, from
$1.4&nbsp;million in 2001 to $0.6&nbsp;million in 2002. The decrease is a result of the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;142, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Goodwill and Other Intangible
Assets</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, and of no longer being required to amortize goodwill and intangible assets with indeterminable lives. During the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2001,
amortization of goodwill amounted to $0.6&nbsp;million. In addition, during 2001 we wrote-off an impaired intangible asset with a net book value of $0.1&nbsp;million and annual
amortization of $0.1&nbsp;million. These decreases were partially offset by the amortization of intangible assets acquired from Inverpower in July&nbsp;2001. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>30</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Restructuring costs.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During April&nbsp;2002, we commenced a restructuring plan designed to streamline our production base,
improve efficiency and enhance our competitiveness and recorded a restructuring charge of $1.5&nbsp;million. The restructuring charge includes approximately $0.6&nbsp;million for severance costs
associated with the reduction of approximately 60 employees, or 17% of the work force. The reductions occurred in the following business segments: Applied Technology&#151;9:
Corporate&#151;2; Electronics&#151;16; and Power Systems&#151;33. On a functional basis, the reductions were: manufacturing&#151;45; research and development&#151;4;
and selling, general and administrative&#151;11. The balance of the restructuring charge relates to the closing of the Anaheim, CA facility. These costs include approximately
$0.3&nbsp;million of cash charges primarily related to rent, real estate taxes and operating costs to be paid through the remainder of the lease and an estimated $0.3&nbsp;million of other cash
charges for restoration and clean-up. In addition, approximately $0.2&nbsp;million of the restructuring charge relates to non-cash charges on assets to be disposed of. The
Anaheim, CA manufacturing facility was closed during fiscal year 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net unrealized loss on warrants to purchase common stock.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net unrealized loss on warrants to purchase common stock decreased
by $1.0&nbsp;million, or 65%, from $1.5&nbsp;million in 2001 to $0.5&nbsp;million in 2002. We account for our warrants to purchase Mechanical Technology Incorporated's common stock and to
purchase Beacon Power's common stock in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;133 and, therefore, we have recorded these warrants at their fair value at September&nbsp;30, 2002 and recorded and unrealized
loss of $0.5&nbsp;million during 2002. The fair value of our warrants to purchase Mechanical Technology Incorporated's common stock decreased by $0.3&nbsp;million from $0.3&nbsp;million to
$0.0&nbsp;million. The fair value of our warrants to purchase Beacon Power's common stock decreased by $0.2&nbsp;million from $0.2&nbsp;million to $0.0&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Write-down of investment in Beacon Power Corporation common stock.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective September&nbsp;28, 2001, we
account for our investment in Beacon Power using the fair value method as set forth in SFAS No.&nbsp;115. At September&nbsp;30, 2002, the fair market value of Beacon Power's common stock was $0.17
per share. Our cost basis in our investment in Beacon Power's common stock was $0.59 per share. As of September&nbsp;30, 2002, we believed the decline in market value represented an other than
temporary decline because, among other things, the market value had been less than cost since March&nbsp;2002 and there was some uncertainty of the financial condition and near-term
prospects of Beacon Power and, accordingly, we recorded an other than temporary write-down of our investment in Beacon Power of $1.4&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other income.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other income decreased by $0.5&nbsp;million, or 79%, from $0.6&nbsp;million in 2001 to $0.1&nbsp;million
in 2002. The decrease is primarily the result of $0.4&nbsp;million decrease in interest income, which is directly related to the decrease in cash, cash equivalents and marketable securities. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Loss from Beacon Power Corporation</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective September&nbsp;28, 2001, we account for our investment in Beacon Power using
the fair value method as set forth in SFAS No.&nbsp;115. We are no longer required to record our share of any losses from Beacon Power and the investment is carried at fair value and is designated
as available for sale, and any unrealized holding gains and losses are to be included in stockholders' equity as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income (loss). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cumulative effect of change in accounting principle.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On October&nbsp;1, 2000, we began accounting for our warrants to
purchase Mechanical Technology Incorporated common stock in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;133 and, therefore, recorded a cumulative unrealized loss of $1.0&nbsp;million as of October&nbsp;1,
2000. On June&nbsp;30, 2001, we began accounting for warrants to purchase our common stock that are designated as a liability in accordance with EITF 00-19,
"</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for Derivative Financial Instruments Indexed to, and Potentially Settled in, a Company's Own Stock</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>", and, therefore, recorded a cumulative
unrealized gain of $1.0&nbsp;million as of June&nbsp;30, 2001 to record the warrants at fair value. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>31</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Quarterly Results of Operations (Unaudited)  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table presents unaudited quarterly statement of operations data for the eight quarters ended September&nbsp;30, 2003. This data has been prepared
on a basis consistent with our audited consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K. This data includes all adjustments, consisting solely
of normal recurring adjustments, that we believe necessary for a fair presentation of this information. The operating results for any quarter are not necessarily indicative of results to be expected
for any future period. The historical quarterly data for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2003 has been adjusted to reflect the impact of recognizing revenue on a funded research and
development contract using the completed-contract method instead of the percentage-of-completion method. The impact of this adjustment was as follows: </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>33</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=34,EFW="2125104",CP="SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=299688,FOLIO='33',FILE='DISK012:[03BOS8.03BOS2708]DM2708A.;15',USER='TMCKINN',CD='23-DEC-2003;11:40' -->
<A NAME="page_dm2708_1_34"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Liquidity and Capital Resources  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of September&nbsp;30, 2003, we had $1.2&nbsp;million of cash, of which $0.5&nbsp;million was restricted, and an outstanding loan balance to Silicon
Valley Bank (the "Bank") of $1.8&nbsp;million. In addition, at September&nbsp;30, 2003 our trade payables totaled $4.7&nbsp;million, of which $3.5&nbsp;million were for invoices over
60&nbsp;days old. In addition, we had $1.3&nbsp;million of accrued accounts payable at September&nbsp;30, 2003 for goods and services received but not yet invoiced. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
October&nbsp;2003, warrants to purchase 1.6&nbsp;million shares of our Common Stock were exercised for net proceeds of $1.5&nbsp;million, we sold an additional
$0.1&nbsp;million of convertible subordinated debentures and we sold shares of series&nbsp;B preferred stock for proceeds of approximately $7.1&nbsp;million, net of placement agent's fees. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
November&nbsp;2003, with the proceeds from these financing transactions, we paid off the outstanding balance under the line of credit of $1.8&nbsp;million and the Bank released
$0.4&nbsp;million of the $0.5&nbsp;million of cash previously restricted. In addition, on December&nbsp;12, 2003, we amended our agreement with the Bank. Under the amended agreement, the Bank
will provide us with a line of credit of up to approximately $6.3 million (the "Amended Loan"). The Amended Loan is secured by most of the assets of the Company and advances under the Amended Loan are
limited to 80% of eligible accounts receivables, which will permit borrowings up to $5.0 million. Interest on outstanding borrowings accrues at a rate equal to the Bank's prime rate of interest plus
1.5% per annum. In addition, we will pay to the Bank a collateral handling fee of 2.4% per annum of the average daily outstanding balance. The interest rate increases to the Bank's prime rate plus
3.0% per annum and the collateral handling fee increases to 3.0% per annum if we fail to meet certain financial ratios. We have also agreed to the
following fees: (i)&nbsp;a $23,250 non-refundable facility fee upon the execution of the agreement; (ii)&nbsp;an unused line fee in an amount equal to 0.50% per annum on the difference
between $5&nbsp;million and the average daily principal balance of the loans outstanding during the month; and (iii)&nbsp;an early termination fee of $25,000 if we terminate the agreement before
June&nbsp;12, 2004. The Amended Loan contains certain financial covenants relating to tangible net worth, as defined, which we must satisfy in order to continue borrowing from the Bank. The Amended
Loan matures on December&nbsp;9, 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
anticipate that our cash after these transactions, together with the availability under the Amended Loan will be sufficient to fund our operations through September&nbsp;30, 2004.
This assumes that we will achieve our business plan and remain in compliance with the Amended Loan. The business plan envisions a significant increase in revenue and significant reductions in the cost
structure and the cash burn rate from the results experienced in the recent past. If, however, we are unable to realize our plan, we may not be in compliance with loan covenants which may cause a
default, as defined, and we may be forced to raise additional funds by selling stock, restructuring its borrowing, selling assets, or taking other actions to conserve our cash position. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If
additional funds are raised in the future through the issuance of equity or convertible debt securities, the percentage ownership of our stockholders will be reduced and our
stockholders may experience additional dilution. The terms of additional funding may also limit our operating and financial flexibility. There can be no assurance that additional financing of any kind
will be available to us on terms acceptable to us, or at all. Failure to obtain future funding when needed or on acceptable terms would materially, adversely affect our results of operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
have recently reevaluated our business in light of recent results and our October financing transactions. As a result of this reevaluation, we have decided to retain our Ling Shaker
product line. And although we continue to consider selling our patented smart predictive line control technology utilized by the electric arc steel manufacturing industry and patents acquired from
Northrop Grumman related to hybrid electric vehicles, these together represent less than $2&nbsp;million of our total assets. We </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>34</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=35,EFW="2125104",CP="SATCON TECHNOLOGY CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=336367,FOLIO='34',FILE='DISK012:[03BOS8.03BOS2708]DM2708A.;15',USER='TMCKINN',CD='23-DEC-2003;11:40' -->
<A NAME="page_dm2708_1_35"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>have
informed our financial advisor, Alliant Capital Partners (an affiliate of the Bank) of our intentions and we are no longer actively working with them to dispose of these assets. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
financial statements for our fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2003, which are included in our Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K, contain an audit report from Grant
Thornton LLP. The audit report contains a going concern qualification, which raises substantial doubt with respect to our ability to continue as a going concern. The receipt of a going concern
qualification may create a concern amongst our current and future customers and vendors as to whether we will be able to fulfill our contractual obligations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
have incurred significant costs to develop our technologies and products. These costs have exceeded total revenue. As a result, we have incurred losses in each of the past five years.
As of September&nbsp;30, 2003, we had an accumulated deficit of $116.7&nbsp;million. Since inception, we have financed our operations and met our capital expenditure requirements primarily through
the sale of private equity securities, public security offerings, borrowings on our line of credit and capital equipment leases. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of September&nbsp;30, 2003, our cash and cash equivalents were $1.2&nbsp;million, including restricted cash and cash equivalents of $0.5&nbsp;million, a decrease of
$0.9&nbsp;million from September&nbsp;30, 2002. Cash used in operating activities for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2003 was $7.3&nbsp;million as compared to $15.3&nbsp;million
for fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2002. Cash used in operating activities during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2003 was primarily attributable to the net loss, net of realized
gain from the sale of Beacon Power Corporation common stock and unrealized gain on warrants to purchase common stock, offset by non-cash items such as depreciation and amortization,
increases in allowances for doubtful accounts and excess and obsolete inventory, unrealized loss from Series&nbsp;B warrants to purchase common stock, write-off of impaired long-lived,
goodwill and intangible assets, write-down of investment in Beacon Power Corporation common stock, non-cash compensation expense and decreases in working capital. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
provided by investing activities during year ended September&nbsp;30, 2003 was $1.5&nbsp;million as compared to of $6.8&nbsp;million for the fiscal year ended
September&nbsp;30, 2002. Cash provided by investing activities during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2003 was primarily the result from proceeds from the sale of our Beacon Power
Corporation common stock of $1.7&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
provided by financing activities for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2003 was $4.8&nbsp;million as compared to cash used by financing activities of $0.3&nbsp;million
for the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2002. Net cash provided by financing activities during the fiscal year ended September&nbsp;30, 2003 includes $3.2&nbsp;million from the proceeds
from the sale of the Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock and the convertible subordinated debentures and $1.8&nbsp;million of net borrowing under the bank line of credit offset by $0.3&nbsp;million of
repayment of long-term debt. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>35</FONT></P>
